Part 1: Predicate Logic 3.1 Expressing Relationship of Humans in Predicate Logic (⋆) Consider, as in the lecture, the universe of all humans (including those who died) and the following predicate: par(x, y) = 1 ⇐⇒ “x is parent of y.” Express the following statements as a formula in predicate logic, using only the above predicates (in particular, do not use the predicate equals, often also written as =). a) x is great-grandparent of y. b) x and y are (ﬁrst) cousins. 3.2 From Natural Language to a Formula (⋆) (4 Points) Consider the universe U = R. Express each of the following statements with a formula in predicate logic, in which the only predicates appearing are less(x, y), equals(x, y), and integer(x) (instead of less(x, y) and equals(x, y) you can write x < y and x = y accord- ingly). You can also use the symbols + and · to denote the addition and multiplication functions, and you can use constants (e.g., 0, 1, . . .). Do not use division. No justiﬁcation is required. i) (⋆) There exists two positive integers whose sum is negative. ii) (⋆) Any real number is not greater than all rational numbers. iii) (⋆) If for every pair of real numbers there exist an integer which is smaller than one of the two and larger than the other, then all real numbers are greater than zero. iv) (⋆ ⋆) All integers whose sum is odd have different parity1. 1Meaning that one is odd and the other is even. 3.3 Winning Strategy (⋆ ⋆) Alice and Bob play a game in which the stake is a chocolate bar. Rules of the game are the following: Alice chooses two integers a1, a2 and Bob chooses two integers b1, b2. Alice wins whenever a1 + (a2 + b1)|b2|+1 = 1 and Bob wins otherwise. a) First, consider the case when Alice and Bob announce all their numbers at the same time. Give a formula that describes the statement “Alice has a winning strategy.” Is this statement true? b) In the second case, Alice and Bob announce their numbers one by one. That is, ﬁrst Alice announces a1, then Bob announces b1, then Alice announces a2, and at the end Bob replies with b2. Once again, give a formula that describes the statement “Alice has a winning strategy.” Is this statement true in this case? Part 2: Proof Patterns 3.4 Indirect Proof of an Implication (2.6.3) Prove indirectly that for all natural numbers n > 0, we have: a) (⋆) If n2 is odd, then n is also odd. b) (⋆ ⋆) If 42n − 1 is a prime, then n is odd. 3.5 Case Distinction (2.6.5) Prove by case distinction that: a) (⋆) n3 + 2n + 6 is divisible by 3 for all natural numbers n ≥ 0. b) (⋆ ⋆) If p and p2 + 2 are primes, then p3 + 2 is also a prime. 3.6 Proof by Contradiction (2.6.6) a) (⋆ ⋆) Show by contradiction that the sum of a rational number and an irrational num- ber is irrational. Hint: Use the fact that the difference of two rational numbers is rational. b) (⋆ ⋆ ⋆) Show that the number 2 1 n is irrational for n > 2, by reaching a contradiction with Fermat’s Last Theorem. Hint: Fermat’s Last Theorem states that no positive integers a, b, c satisfy the equation a n + bn = cn for n > 2. 3.7 New Proof Patterns (⋆) (4 Points) For each of the following proof patterns, prove or disprove that it is sound. a) (⋆) To prove a statement S, ﬁnd two appropriate statements T1 and T2. Assume that S is false and show (from this assumption) that one between the statements T1 and T2 is true. Then show that one statement between T1 and T2 is false. b) (⋆) To prove an implication S ⇒ T , ﬁnd an appropriate statement R. Assume that S is true and T is false, and prove that (from these assumptions) R is true. Then show that R is false. Due on 12. October 2023, 23:59. Exercises 3.2 and 3.7 are graded.
